reviewText:
It may surprise some people to learn that, before playing Joe Dever‚Äôs Lone Wolf HD Remastered, I hadn‚Äôt heard of the series or the author. A quick Google revealed that Joe began writing the Lone Wolf books back in the late 80s‚Äô, and the character has also made appearances in videogames and gamebooks ‚Äì the novels alone have sold over 9 million copies!  Lone Wolf HD casts you as the titular character,  the mysterious Liege Lord of Sommerlund. A ruler of his people, who has sworn to protect them from any threat, no matter how big. But don‚Äôt be fooled by this description or the screenshots floating around the internet, Lone Wolf HD is a text-heavy gamebook first and foremost, and a turn-based RPG second.

You start off by customising the Lone Wolf to your liking, choosing his skills and traits which you‚Äôll be able to use during the game to overcome difficult situations. The game quickly launches into its lore, telling of a snowy, mountainous land reminiscent of games like Skyrim.

The village of Rockstarn has been set ablaze, her people murdered and their belongings stolen. You soon discover that a foul horde of Giaks is responsible for this heinous crime. With your sword in hand you set about thinning out their numbers, whilst looking for survivors and clues as to why this has happened. These sequences take two forms: turn based combat, and choice-driven story. As you progress through the game, you will be presented with meaningful choices, and how you approach them can benefit you or come back to haunt you later in your quest. Every dilemma gives you a number of choices, each relevant to a particular skill you may or may not have mastered. While some situations call for a more direct approach, others may require tact on your part, to achieve the desired results.

The Lone Wolf‚Äôs story is of epic proportions, and you‚Äôll travel across Sommerlund to take the fight to Giak hordes and their masters. Your map is marked with various locations and merchants where you can stock up on provisions. Exploring each location furthers the story and takes you deeper into your quest to find out why the people of Rockstarn have been murdered. The land is overrun with enemies though, and you‚Äôll have to lay waste to them to protect your people.

Combat is turn-based and you must complete your attacks within a time limit, after which the enemy will begin their assault. You‚Äôll go up against a variety of different beasts during your quest, ranging from bog-standard Giaks to their superiors, the formidable Drakkarim, and the terrifying Red Fang. Lone Wolf has a number of powerful attacks in his arsenal to overcome his foe, as well as various arms and side arms. You‚Äôll also be able to call upon your Kai power, a kind of mental ability that only few have a mastery of, to launch debilitating psychological attacks. The options available to you are also linked directly to the skills you chose during the game‚Äôs opening, so it is worth keeping that in mind when choosing your skills. Combat is quick, fluid and fun, but it‚Äôs a shame that some special moves require quick cursor rotations or directional flicks. Undoubtedly, this would have been responsive and intuitive in the iOS version of the game, but on PC it feels a little bit clunky and un-optimised. That‚Äôs not to say it spoils the combat, but the thought that your cursor movements might not have been accurate enough is always there. While the combat is engaging it serves merely to break up long sections of the book and, ultimately, you‚Äôll be anxious to get back to reading it.

And what a book it is. Mr Dever‚Äôs mastery of his craft is immediately apparent, as he weaves a complex but approachable tale filled with interesting characters and locations. His masterful descriptions created images so rich in my minds-eye that I could almost feel the heat, and smell the acrid smoke, of Rockstarn as it burned to the ground. You will spend most of your time reading, so be aware that the only GPU getting a workout won‚Äôt be inside your computer, it‚Äôs inside your head. It‚Äôs at this point that I should disclose that I am not much of a reader, but found Joe Dever‚Äôs Lone Wolf HD Remastered to be an addictive and gripping tale. I‚Äôd encourage anyone with even a passing interest in fantasy books to give The Lone Wolf some of their time.

As an iOS port, I wasn‚Äôt expecting much from the game graphically, and, truth be told, it‚Äôs a bit of a mixed bag. While the menus, book and illustrations are all rendered nicely, the 3D combat sections do suffer from some graphical disparity. The Lone Wolf and his enemies all feature detailed animations and textures, but the surroundings they‚Äôll be fighting in are low-resolution and low-poly. Luckily, these jarring differences are offset by how brief combat tends to be. The game‚Äôs score can‚Äôt be faulted though, and while there‚Äôs only a handful of unique tracks they run from rousing to melancholic, and are played at suitable intervals ‚Äì it‚Äôs also included in your download for your listening pleasure!

Whilst it does have its drawbacks, Joe Dever‚Äôs Lone Wolf HD Remastered is a stunning example of the gamebook genre, brought to life on PC. Featuring an engrossing mix of story and turn-based combat, it‚Äôs sure to appeal to people with an appreciation of a deep lore. Completionists will also get bang for their buck, with the choice-driven narrative lending itself well to replayability. For the Sommerlund and the Kai, you must buy this game!

As a kid, I loved the Lone Wolf book series.  These books were my first introduction real RPGs.  So when I tripped over this during the Thanksgiving Sale, you can imagine my excitement.

Friends and fans of the old-fashioned adventure books, it does not dissapoint.

The game basically plays like an alternate version/continuation of the Lone Wolf adventure book series.  While a newcomer to the series might feel a touch lost, the opening sums things up beautifully and character creation is a breeze.  Everything is so clear and concise.  Most importantly though, *your choices actually matter*!

Much like the original books, every decision you make reverberates through your adventure.  I'm only starting the second chapter, but I am thouroughly hooked, weighing each choice carefully before I make it.  Especially when said choices can impact the combat encounters.

Oh yes, the combat.  If you're a fan of Paper Mario or South Park: Stick of Truth, this should feel rather familiar.  Select target, choose an attack, maybe do a quick-time event for more damage.  All turn-based, pretty standard stuff (though the graphics are absolutely GORGEOUS!).  But the biggest draw to combat is how it ties to your choices leading up to it!

You spot a group of enemies.  Do you sneak up on them?  Charge in and try to catch them off-guard?  Spend some of your limited supernatural power to try and sneak past them?  Whatever choice you makes carries into the combat, rendering enemies weaker or even avoiding combat all together if you choose well, or possibly giving them a chance to strike first if you fail at your attempt.  And just like in the books, while combat can be exciting, you feel the limit of your health and items.  The game feels very rewarding when the right choice leads to an easier fight.

I cannot stress this enough:  If you ever liked the Lone Wolf books, get this game.  If you're a fan of RPGs in general and you've never heard of the Lone Wolf books, go read about them on TVTropes or something and then *GET THIS GAME.*  You're not just buying an immersive game, you're paying homage to a piece of Roleplaying history.

reviewText:
I've played this game all the way from the time when it was still being released by episodic on iOS. The gameplay certainly is different from what one may be used to if one has played the original gamebooks. I was surprised at first, but eventually find that this is quite a refreshing way to explore the world of Lone Wolf.

Artwork is absolutely gorgeous! Loved seeing Lone Wolf actually portrayed in his full glory for the first time ever, albeit still in his early years as a Kai Lord. The transition from paper to 3D and back is a great touch. Battle backgrounds are varied according the player's location when attacked.

The soundtrack is pretty good as well, well suited for the environment and events. They add to the mystique, danger, sorrow of whichever fortunate, or unfortunate event that occurred in the game world.

Battles require players to understand the mechanism and adapt to something completely different from the gamebooks. It also may seem repetitive, but personally, I feel that it's unavoidable for a game of this caliber. The freedom of movement and random battles aim to help the player to get used to fighting a certain enemy, gain items and gold, as well as provide the player with the ability to have some control over moving in an area. It allows the player to break free from the typical gamebook linearity where they must perform certain XYZ actions at a specific time, and no other (i.e. purchase from merchants. or training skills).

A lot of balancing changes have been made to the battle system since it was first released. I find it quite well balanced compared to initial release. Some battle elements appear to be random, unfair and hard, but if one played the original gamebooks properly (i.e. without cheating), one may find themselves on the verge of death or dying quite often as well.

Not a fan of QTEs, but I feel that this game has it done right for the general user. They are doable as long as the player remembers what QTE action is required for which combat skill. The QTEs are fixed for almost every battle action, and events (as long as you can memorize the QTEs every event in the game). The controls are intuitive for the mouse, and does not impose strict directional movements on the player (i.e. the swipe does not have to be a definite 45 degree semi-circular movement to be executed).

Statistics can rise depending on the actions the player decides to take during an event. Repeated usage of weapon skills will eventually lead to an additional bonus for that particular skill. Crafting to improve weapons, armours and certain items are a welcome surprise. (I only miss my Sommersack from the iOS). There are some puzzles in the game to give variety, but not that much that it takes too much from the gameplay.

This is certainly an interesting way to breath life into a gamebook, what with many other companies already creating digital gamebooks that adhere more or less to the standards of a paperback (i.e. dice-rolling, turn to page ###).

Sure, it's not perfect (seriously, what is?), but a truly excellent work from both the original creator of Lone Wolf, and the developer of this game.

reviewText: Outstandingly realised conversion of an interactive gamebook. It does away with the old cumbersome turn to page <whatever> to go left and <whatever> to go right" (unlike the inferior conversions of the Games Workshop titles) with nice use of a direction selecting map. The combat is difficult at first but satisfying as you progress and become used to the many variations on its time-based system. You actually feel as if you are becoming physically and mentally more skillful the more you play. Every stage of the game works on choices and consequences but you never feel as if you are bogged down or distracted by the medium itself. All the dice rolls etc. are handled and masked by the software in such a way that you realise what is going on but the sytem never intrudes on your immersion. It's difficult to imagine how a game of this nature could have been accomplished in a way to make it any better than it actually is. Equipment can be improved through crafting and is customisable in such a way that the new benefits are clearly understood and actively felt. I want more like this and as long as you can keep in mind that it IS a conversion of a set system you should love it. Get it. 97%"

The game is average, but it has its own uniqueness. Its like an interactive book with multiple tools to get the job done with slight variation to how the game unfolds.

The narative is stylish and done close to how the upcoming 'Hand of Fate' is done, but is somewhat different. Its fancy, rich in details and vivid, making it really easy to picture the events unfolding. Seriously its like an ok fantasy book.

The 'various weapons' are not so various at all its the same 3 weapons with slightly different stats and sometimes a different model. Now the animations are done well *even the comical faces of enemies during the mana restoration finishers* and the gameplay is on the point fluid, but with little variation to it it eventually will get dull no matter what. Too many battles with too little variation.

Soundtrack was distracting and filled with disturbing background noises of a muted phone under a pillow a few meters away.

Overall its a solid game, definite few hours of fun, unless  you are impartial to the storytelling narrative, which this game does great.

Overall easy 6-7/10. Worth a puchase when its on sale.

reviewText:
This is a recommendation that borders right on the 50ish out of 100 score, making it a toss-up between 'buy this' or 'don't buy this'.  Keeping in mind that I have yet to pass five or so hours in game yet and this is based only on the first chapter, my biggest problem is this.

There is so.  Much.  RNG.

Restating, there is nothing wrong with Random Number Generator-based anything.  Every game relies on RNG.  Sometimes your attack goes through, sometimes it's blocked, sometimes it's parried, sometimes you get lucky, sometimes not.  The problem with Lone Wolf is how shatteringly screwed you can be by the RNG, and there is not a single thing you can do about it.

The fighting consists of two phases for you; an attack phase and a rest phase.  During your attack phase, a timer ticks down how long you have to make your attacks, drink your potions, etc.  You can do multiple things per turn, until you eat up all your END (physical actions), MANA (magic actions) or run out of time.  Your END recovers very slowly during your attack phase and very quickly during your rest phase, with your MANA barely recovering at all until you kill an enemy.  However, while YOU cannot attack in your rest phase, enemies can attack ALL THE TIME, operating on their own (hidden) attack and rest phases.  You can and will be interupted while you go to select an attack by an enemy launching his attack first, preventing you from acting on a strategy or idea.

RNG as I already stated is beyond intolerable at times.  The very first attack launched against you, you might dodge.  Or  it can stun you, you lose your turn, and are unable to act while enemies deal 1500 damage to you (very realistic damage, considering even within the first 3-4 battles they start throwing 3 enemies at a time at you).  Or you might dodge all these attacks and then launch your own POWERFUL attack on an enemy.  He might take the hit and lose 50% of his health, or he might counter it, take 10% damage, and you have just wasted 50% of your END, better luck next time.

The point of this is that it boils down to the right set of circumstances happening to let you succeed.  Being stunned in turn 1 can sometimes be an instant game-over, as you lose your turn and are reduced to nearly no HP and struggling to recover.  5 minutes into the fight, you might be selecting your sword to kill an enemy when he swigs back a potion (Even basic enemies have potions, by the way, hope you don't mind your fodder healing themselves), and he now has more HP than you can dish out, preventing you from killing him, preventing you from replenishing your mana, preventing you from healing the next round, meaning you died.

And this is all topped off with the fact that you can restart every battle from the beginning.  So what happens?

You restart.  A lot.

Not even from dying, either.  Enemy dealt a shattering crit on their first move?  Restart, this time you parry it.  Enemy stunned you at the wrong time?  Restart, hope that doesn't happen this time.  I have had cases where I have restarted certain fights upwards of 15-20 times until the RNG simply decided it was a good time to let me win, and the enemies didn't pull any shenanigans and my attacks went off without a hitch.

Bottom line of all this: The game is pretty and sounds nice, fantastic.  But the gameplay itself suffers horrendously not because of actual mechanics, but because all the behind-the-scenes calculations rely entirely on a very erratic RNG system that can leave you decimating your enemies easily or getting royally screwed over on your very first turn.  If you buy this game, be prepared to accept that a great deal of your time will involve slamming that ESC key, restarting the battle, and just praying that RNGesus is kind to you this time.

reviewText: I'd never heard of Lone Wolf 24 hours ago. I paid $7.49 for this game, and it was beyond worth it. I've played just under thirty minutes. This game feels great. You get to create a customized character in minutes, those choices immediately affect the story you are reading and the combat you will face. The story events are between old school text based adventures and quick time events. It blends your decisions with your actions beautifully. The turn based combat doesn't let you walk away. You have limited time and resources to take actions, so you need to make snap decisions. To be effective you need to stay calm and focused. This makes the combat thrilling, and did I mention this game looks pretty too. The way they blend art from the book into the combat sequences is stunning. The graphics aren't what you would see on a next gen console, but they look good. As far as animation is concerned, I have to say they nailed it. From throwing knives to having your chest slashed open, the models move fluidly. I definitely recommend picking Lone Wolf up if you have $10 to spare.\n\nEdit: Now that I have almost ten hours under my belt, I would like to expand this review a little bit. I started another character because I didn't see how it was possible to survive without certain skills. Turns out I was wrong. You can definitely take whatever starting skills you are interested in trying. Sometimes enemies will wreck your day. When it happens, you may not even get to defend yourself because it is absolutely possible to become stun locked. It isn't likely, and because the game uses a random element, it is also completely possible for you to dodge every attack in a fight. You will probably die a couple of times during a fight that you are prepared for due to bad luck. It makes it far more rewarding when you try again and slaughter your enemies. If you really get stuck, the game even has the option to drop the difficulty a step when you retry. I should also talk about replay value after making a second character. It's okay. If you choose different skills at the beginning of the game, and you try taking another path through each of the obstacles in the game, then it isn't too repetitive. Many of the fights will be the same or nearly the same unless you had the option to avoid one completely. When you know what you are doing, you can definitely work through the fights faster, and it feels like you are accomplishing something rather than grinding because the story actually moves as you cut down your enemies. I can't say how long a run through this campaign should take. I just set the game on hard, turned off hints, and charged into the fray.

reviewText:
If you liked the Lone Wolf series back in the 80's, this is probably a childhood fantasy come to life.

Be aware, this is an interactive book with more reading than anything else, but it is as well written as ever when it comes to Joe Dever's style.  Reading is separated by quick-time events - whether it's the combat system itself (there is a slight bit more to it than quick-time like picking what type of attack etc.) or an action event where you have to quickly react after you've made a questionable decision.

As for everything else, you start off by choosing your gimmicks (animal kinship, camoflouge, mindblast, etc.) just like the good ole' days and it takes off from there.  The page artwork is fantastic (black & white pencil sketches like the books, but brought to life), and the combat uses 3D with pretty good quality models and environments.  Music is dynamic and quite well done (title screen reminded me of Loreena McKennitt).

All in all, I give it two thumbs up (graciously donated by the the Giak I just killed).

reviewText:
After having played Lone Wolf for 10 hours, I have decided to write a review for the first time since I joined steam. My intent in doing so is to share my view, with my fellow gamers, that this game deserves to be played and enjoyed.

When I saw Lone Wolf on the main page I immediately had a flashback of the books that I used to read/play when I was a kid. This being said, I was prudent before buying because the last thing I wanted was to experience a disapointment that would taint my memory of such a great experience I had playing these books. I was especially worried about the Quick Time Events (QTEs), as I really hate those in a game (QTEs usually means a shortcut to me, one that the developper took instead of developping a combat system for example) This being said, I didnt want this game to be a hack/slash either. So I took a chance after having read the positive reviews.

The game is essentially split in two parts: Reading the story and making choices, based on your stats and character's specifics, and combat/action events.

The story itself is true to the Lone Wolf books. Well written, engaging, and detailled enough so that you can perceive or visualize the envrionement in which you evolve. There are also pretty cool pictures once in a while. The choices you make in the story determines where you go, who joins or assist you, what loot you may get, and how you engage in fights.

The combat and action events takes you out of the story format and brings you into a live event where you see yourself fighting enemies. The combat is similar to a turn based like Final Fantasy (time bar until it is your turn). When it is your turn, you have a certain time to execute as many actions as you want/can based on your endurance and energy points. It is here that you need to be smart to efficiently determine when and how you will play certain moves and how you will combine them to maximize their efficiency.

The enemies are hard but not unfair. If you die, it is because you should probably have spent that endurance on a defensive move rather than that other move. Some people say QTEs are unfair in combat, because, yes, sometime if you miss one, it results in the enemy landing a more heavy hit. I personally see this as a test of your reflex (which evidently you would have to show in combat or any combat game) The QTEs becomes rather easy after a while anyway. I currently play on normal and find the difficulty just right.

The character developments is also more complex than I originally thought. It seems your stats raises based on what choices you make during certain acts. For example, if you make a choice that would result on a action based on your dexterity, it will result in a better chance for you to increase your dexterity at the end of the act. Also, the more you use certain skills, the more these will level up, granting you more bonuses in those skills.

You can also collect items to forge and level up your equipment. It is not a deep item crafting system, but it keeps you on your toes to manage your item and money. The bonuses to upgrading your equipment are essential.

Overall, great engaging story, good enough fighting system for a game based on books, great music (really). I will replay many times to try out different skills combination.

Have you ever heard of the books that this game is based on?  If not I highly recommend you engage in one of the best Choose your Own Adventure series of all time.  This game is based on one of my favorite fantasy worlds of all time.  And I say that without attempting to establish a bias.  Without lying, I am a total fan of the books and have wanted the IOS copy of this game for some time.  I just never had a phone that could run it.  That being said, I jumped on this as soon as it was available.  So was it worth it?

Thus far, the issues that people may have with this game, is the fact that you are essentially, reading a modernized version of one of the choose your own adventure books.  There is no real vocal nararation outside of the introduction to each chapter.  Beyond that, you the player will be reading the book, and interacting with all the choices and game mechanics in a sort of quick time event laden skill test.  Now let me start by saying I hate quick time events.  I hate them.  But in this case, given the IOS port nature of the game, they are a tolerable evil, that still works with the game.

I have not played the game to date on any difficulty below the hardest... and in doing so, I have found that I literally have to budget a strategy in fights down the the precise second of battle where I need to drink a potion.  Unfortunately, I have had a couple of moments where the games RNG has decided that I would not even get to take a turn as soon as battle starts before the enemy slaughters me with no quarter.  There is a heavy element of RNG, so I am not entirely keen on the idea of that being the only real difficulty.

There is a lack of music variety, but what you get is good quality stuff.  The sound effects are also not ear sores.  The game also seems to come into a length of around two and a half to three hours per Act, with four Acts to complete the whole game.  That is a base estimate, it can easily be done faster, and again, I am on the hardest difficulty, so I am certain the game can be cleared much faster on the easier stuff.

All and all this is a completely solid IOS port, fully playable with virtually no gameplay related issues, except for how the touch spots work. reviewText:
Lone Wolf is a well balanced, decently challenging RPG where the combat seems to take a semi-tactical aspect in how you approach it. The game plays mostly like the books it is based on, exept the adaptation allows better tracking of stats and the various choices you make during gameplay. The game carry a good atmosphere and story, given that the main visual outside of combat is text based, we feels everything the character goes through. While the way the story is portrayed may not speak to everyone, the combat aspect is engaging, there are numerous contextual QTE to most action, sometimes while using skills outside of combat, and reall keeps the user invested in the fight. Combat is turn based, but your turn only last as long as one of your stats allow, and enemies attack as soon they can which may also be while 'your turn' plays out. On this side the combat require a bit more finesse and quick thinking than average for an RPG.
I seriously cannot really speak of a bad aspect of this game, none come to mind. Every skills are balanced and mostly as useful outside of combat or in combat, some may be redundant at times while in the next instance you're glad to have the only skill which can help you. For the price which is not very demanding considering what we've seen in the past, this game is well worth the money and time.

Have fun and play hard!

P.S. The main character remind me of a Witcher from the witcher serie, hehe.

I loved back in past Joe Dever's Lone Wolf Game Books a lot, but i think they were much better than this game.
I had great expectations from this game but my fears were confirmed when i tried the fighting sections...
About the lore and the story nothing to say, it's like the old Lone Wolf i remember, but the real pain happens when you meet an enemy.

First thing, in the old books, when you was facing an enemy it was most often a 1 vs 1, while here, in the videogame, almost always is you vs 3 enemies together in a sort of Turn Based like (it's not 100% turn based but is very similar) fight, almost always ends up with you dead forced to restart the fight again and again till some luck not goes to your side, yes because the fights are totally random with the chances you get smashed hard at beginning or you can dodge the first attack, giving you more opportunities to survive.

I  resisted for some chapters but more you go deep with the story more the difficulty increases and i did not find any special items that helped me to become much stronger than what i was at the beginning, so the combat system and toughness and number of the enemies make this game , at high levels, very very frustrating and nearly impossible to progress in some point.

So my final vote is positive cause i was used to love Lone wolf when i was young and the fashion of the character still works also in this game, but sadly the combat system and the not balanced difficulty at Hard ruined the real fun for this game that could have been much better.

Recommended to the old fans of the books only, most of them would probably be forced to play this game at lower difficulty.

My final vote is  7/10

I was indifferent to this game from the outset.  I had first seen this game as an iOS/mobile game, so I was more (morbidly?) curious with how they would handle the port than the game itself.

My Let's Play - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W4dLAmGuAdA

Spoiler: While the port itself is excellent in presentation, there are still lots of gesture-commands to handle input.  This isn't a terrible thing as all of the combat scenes are nothing more than a series of QTE++ sequences, but still.  I wish there were additional input methods available.

That small complaint aside, I can start to see the attraction to VNs.  Lone Wolf started as a series of Gamebooks (choose your own adventure) and as far as I can see it's literally the interactive version of that.  Complete with battle sequences, lock-picking and attempting different situations via one of four special powers that you picked when you created your character.  An example would be the animal kinship trait that helps you past a situation by communing with wildlife for secret intel.

It's not fast paced but I found myself interested in the story and my part in it.  Mission accomplished as far as I'm concerned.

reviewText:
I love the Lone Wolf books.  I saw them for the first time when I was really young, and I was enthralled by the amazing world Joe Dever created.  With just one book, 'Flight from the Dark', I was hooked on the adventures of Lone Wolf, last of the Kai Lords, as he fought the Darklords of Helgedad and the forces of the god of darkness, Naar.

Joe Dever does not disappoint with this game.  The writing, world building and feel of the story is a perfect match to the old CYOA books.  From the first moments of the game, you feel like you really are Lone Wolf, the last hope for Sommerlund.

It's an absolute travesty that this fantastic writing is ruined by positively garbage game design.  All of the problems in this game revolve around combat which, incidentally, was one of the biggest stumbling points in the original book series.  In the book series, it was because Dever had to write around the player potentially having the Infinity +1 Sword (The Sommerswerd).  In this game, it is because the designers couldn't be ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to make a fighting system that relied on something other than RNG and confusion.

The game has four chapters.  The first two, it is worth noting, are fantastic.  The combat is simple and to the point.  Enemies can hit decently hard, but you are well equipped to handle them and supplies are plentiful.  It isn't that the games design is better at this point, it is that the flaws are easier to overlook.  Combat will rarely be fatal, even if it takes a turn for the worse, and this keeps the player moving through the story, which is the real meat of the game.

The final boss of the second chapter is where things start to get really rough.  The enemy will go first, deals massive damage, and has a chance to stun you.  If you are stunned in this opening salvo, you WILL die before getting a chance to act at all.  The chance of this happening isn't too high, but it is still there, and most players will see it at least once, if not more.

From then on, the game pulls no punches, in the worst ways possible.  Random encounters are BOSS level mobs, which make it easier to just reload an old save then to deal with the pointless slugfest.  Enemy monsters are filled with 'Rapid Clicking QTEs', which seem to be used for almost everything in the game.  Early on, you'd take some damage or screw an attack up if you failed.  Now?  Dead if you mess it up.

I got sick and tired of it and just installed an auto clicker.  And even with that, it only makes the combat slightly LESS unfair.  You WILL die, many times, to swarms of foes before you can possibly react.  100% to dead before you can do anything, even if you were defending.  Adding onto everything else, the enemy is not held to the same mechanical rules that the player is.

Lone Wolf can act during his own 'phase'.  When his timer runs out, he cannot act for a bit, and then the cycle repeats.  The enemy has no such difficulty.  They can attack whenever they wish, your phase or not.  They can attack the millisecond your defenses drop (and often will) and hit with DoT effects that deal huge chunks of your health (similar DoTs are nearly scratch damage to them).

The original books were about controlling conflict.  You weren't an army slaying warrior, so you were supposed to be clever about how you engaged in fights.  This game not only forgot that, but went the other way and puts you into bland, annoying and uninteresting combat CONSTANTLY.

If you want a good story, I can recommend this game.  But I'd advise you to play Chapter 1 and 2 on Normal, then slam it down to Easy to just burn through the rest of the story without the BS.  There's no reason to give yourself a migrane over Difficulty by Frustration.""

reviewText:
As someone who thoroughly enjoyed the book series I was excited to play this when I first heard of it. Having completed the playthough I found myself captured to the end and await a sequal.

There is alot of parts to the game I found very enjoyable and not much I could point out for improvement, the game is a solid effort and well rounded. I really enjoyed both the combat and non-combat sections of the game and found it to be rather challenging, so felt rewarded when I had successes throughout the game.

Story: The story of the game was done well much like the books were, I think it was a good implementation. Even where mistakes were made (I fell foul of a trap in the game after i thought i had overcome it...was cursing myself afterwards too haha), I was glad to see that it was indeed possible to make a story choice that would cost you your life in the game. Also reflecting on the game there were story choices that had both obvious outcomes and not so obvious outcomes which i thought was good, though personal preference would have me request more of the latter.

Combat: As for combat... NAILED IT. I loved everything about the combat in the game. The combat mechanics were solid, i especially liked the fact you could overexert yourself at the expense of your own wellbeing.

Some games allow you to adopt a fairly static playstyle, I usually find myself never really needing to use consumables... in this however they were very much a requirement, I actually found myself stocking up on poison arrows or throwing blades... I found myself throwing down stunpowder just to give myself some breathing room in some of the fights... I also found myself NOT doing area attacks in some situations because i didn't want to break the mindblast i did on an that Drakkarim... or chugging down a... stamina potion... just so I could disarm that vordak.
I must say i never felt so relieved as when I took down 2 of those accursed things and a gourgaz that attacked me at once... that was a tough fight and I had to laugh when the giak came after the 3 of them fell and tried to be all tough.
Actually if i had one criticism about the combat scenes... at the end of them there needs more variation in the post combat animations... usually he's just standing there with his 2 weapons (i ran with 2 axes or sword+axe) and kinda looked like a try hard.

Bugs: - I didn't encounter a single bug... across the whole game...

Audio: Sound track i found thematic and made good ambience, the sound effects from the fight scenes themselves were satisfying and not overdone or underdone, maybe some more variation in the enemy roars at the start of a fight scene would have topped it off. Instead of every enemy roaring, having curses, insults, shrieks, to mix it up a little would have staved off the little bit of repetiveness i noticed here. Same with grunts and shouts when executing attacks.

Graphics: The graphics/Art tied in well to the feeling of the game i think that was trying to be achieved. The enemies all looked amazing, the last enemy of the game looked a bit cartoony i felt compared to the rest of the game(especially his death scene), but he was the pimped out big bad evil guy with ancient artifacts, so i get it.

Overall if you ever read the books, you will probably enjoy this game as it's got the same feel (I found it slightly more casual than the books truth be told, but minor point).
If you're new to the Lone wolf world then you will find this game refreshingly different to other RPG's, If you like challenges then i suspect you will like this game, as your choices do matter and affect your game experience with both positive and negative outcomes for the actions you take.

reviewText: This game definitely won't be for everyone, but I've been totally hooked since I bought it.  Be warned straight away, that the game is half book, half RPG combat/inventory management, and I mean that literally (you spend much of your time turning pages in a virtual book and reading).  It's based on the Lone Wolf CYOA books, and stays true to that formula for the most part.   Half of the game is simply reading the progressing story and making decisions on how to handle situations.  I will say that it's not nearly as difficult or high stakes as the original Lone Wolf books were, as most encounters can be handled whichever way you decide to go.  The other half of the game is a turn based / real-time hybrid RPG combat system (kind of like Final Fantasy 6/7 or Chrono Trigger, except with multiple actions available in one turn), which is surprisingly fun.  The difficulty seems to be balanced perfectly on normal difficulty (at least for myself), which keeps it engaging, though the combat can be a bit repetitive with a lack of variety of different enemies and only one party member.\n\nIf the idea of combining a CYOA book with a well balanced, fun, but slightly repetitive RPG combat system sounds interesting to you, check it out.  The writing isn't amazing, but it isn't terrible.  The art is cool, but limited.  The music is similarly nice, but very limited...in the end though, the real fun of the game for me is in making your own decisions as you roleplay your character, and the tough but fair combat.

reviewText: I do recommend this game for what it is. I love the book approach to the rpg genre. I love the way the story is written in most cases. As a gamer that is also an avid reader, I can appreciate this game on two fronts and that makes a huge difference. However, not all is great in this review. What could have been a solid 9 out of 10, has to be demoted to a 7 out of 10 score from me. The culprit that's dragging this amazing game down with it? QUICK TIME EVENTS! The entire combat system is heavily dependant on them, and there's really NO NEED for such lazy mechanics that are more suited to a game that's to be played on your cell phone than on your computer. With a proper turn based combat system, this game would have been a 9 out 10 for me. As it sits, it's still worth playing, but the developers really need to rethink the quick time events moving forward in my opinion, as it detracts from the gameplay and the rpg mechanics that are otherwise spectacular.
